Title: Linking forum posts - dynamics1-001-02-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Module 44: Error in impulse-momentum equation? (dimensions mismatched)
Input.posts:
In Module 44, we start with the linear impulse-momentum equation (where both sides are in dimensions of force x time ) and the angular impulse-momentum equation (where both sides are in dimensions of force x distance x time ). The two equations are then simply combined as-is to yield the final equation: But this results in mismatched dimensions: we're adding force terms and moment terms together. Shouldn't the linear I-M equation be multiplied by a moment arm before combining it with the angular I-M equation? This in fact is done in the subsequent example problem; i.e., the force and linear momentum terms are multiplied by a moment arm. Aside from that apparent inconsistency, given that the linear and angular I-M equations must each hold, is there any real advantage to combining them into one equation rather than treating them as separate simultaneous equations?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Bert: There's not an advantage to combining them. And yes, treating them as separate simultaneous equations will avoid the dimension problem. Thank you for pointing this out. Sincerely, Dr. Wayne Whiteman
Instructor's post : Hi Bert: There's not an advantage to combining them. And yes, treating them as separate simultaneous equations will avoid the dimension problem. Thank you for pointing this out. Sincerely, Dr. Wayne Whiteman
Upvotes:
0

Input.threadtitle: Lecture module 46 question about moment of inetria
Input.posts:
we can see in this problem the bar is rotating about point O. So we should use moment of inertia I=(m*l^2)/3 but we use I= (m*l^2)/12 like if the bar rotate about point of center. Why?

Title: Linking forum posts - dynamics1-001-02-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
RequesterFeedback: Hi, please be parsimonious in your marking. Not all the people in the thread posted solutions so you can assume that the instructor is not replying to them, hence do not mark them
Input.threadtitle: Module 20 question about acceleration of pont of contact
Input.posts:
In this video we've walked through derivation of acceleration of that point of the wheel which is in contact with the surface. Ok, it's clear, that velocity of this point is zero. Next, we end up with nonzero acceleration of this point, and this is very strange, cause i can't understand how the derivative of zero can be something other then zero?
Upvotes:
0
Without going into the mathematics, think about it this way: we know that, at the precise moment of this snapshot, that point's velocity is zero. If its acceleration also happened to be zero, it would mean that, in the next moment, the point would continue to have zero velocity, and in the next after that, etc. There would be no motion.
Upvotes:
0
Dear Alexey. Imagine, tha you hold a mass in your hand (zero velocity) and live it to fall down. What is the accelaration of the mass? This is the garvitational acceleration (g=9,8 m/s2) This acceleration is the derivative of the zero velocity!
Upvotes:
0
Ok, i can imagine it, but how it can be mathematically that the derivative of zero velocity is nonzero? Why in case with point C (center of the wheel) we can take derivative of velocity and get it's acceleration but in the case of point of contact derivative don't give us right answer? Cause point C is moving rectilinear? This is why we can get acceleration of pont C directly from derivative of it's velocity?
Upvotes:
0
Acceleration is the derivative of velocity with respect to time. It measures the instantaneous change in velocity from one moment to the next. It doesn't matter if velocity at this particular moment is zero or 1 ,000,000 m/s , because the derivative measures the difference between the velocity at this instant and the next.
Upvotes:
0
In these pictures I ivestigated the velocity and the acceleration of different points of a weel, moving with constant velocity. See the case at Lambde=1, when y=0, that is the point I, and at that point a vertical acceleration will insure the given path...
Upvotes:
0
I'd like to rewrite the final equations, explaining the meaning of the terms:
Upvotes:
0
This is the same with the equation of the acceleration:
Upvotes:
2
I prefere the graphic solutions, because easier recognize the mistakes. Here I copy the solution of the Quizze 3:
Upvotes:
1
Dear László Kocsis Thanks for your wonderful posting., this could help those- including myself - who made careless mistakes in week 3 quiz, The concept of Instantaneous centers slipped my mind and impulsively concluded that the the angular vel of Member AB is zero when in fact it is 1 rad/s Simple as ( 2 times five equals 10 times 1)
Upvotes:
0
